text:
It is understood that due to (historic mostly?) reasons, mod_ssl cannot be
distributed as freely as the rest of apache. But since for probably 99+ % of the
people downloading apache, this is a non-issue, I suggest to at least safely
warn naive admin's that in the case they did not touch the httpd.conf file in an
SSL-related way, just because "apachectl sslstart" didn't thow out any warnings,
that doesn't mean SSL is operational. In fact, one may easily end up with a
running httpd that lets users access 443 with http (not httpS).
Therefore, my suggestion is to check in httpd for the mod_ssl.so and other key
variables determinig whether SSL is properly deployed when -DSSL is used on the
command line at start-up.

P.S.: the companion request to similarly improve apachectl is in
http://nagoya.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=15623
creator: hauser@acm.org
slive@apache.org
text:
Two things:

1. apachectl startssl is deprecated.  If there is some documentation that
says otherwise, please point it out so we can fix it.  (The SSL docs in
general are not perfectly up-to-date.)

2. The fact that apachectl startssl does not throw an error message when
mod_ssl is not present is caused by some strategically placed 
<IfModule mod_ssl> lines.  I have long opposed these lines for just this
sort of reason, but other developers want them there to make apache
work "out of the box" in more situations.  So, even though I agree
it is bad, it is a design decision and not a bug.

Thanks for using Apache!

Re 1): http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/ssl/ssl_faq.html in the "About
Configuration" Section in the question "Why do I get ``Connection Refused''
messages when trying to access my freshly installed Apache+mod_ssl server via
HTTPS?"

Re 2): OK, but please at least put something like the following additional line
into the apachectl script:
echo "For apache2 and if mod_ssl.so is present, the use of the option 'startssl'
is deprecated"
creator: hauser@acm.org

text:
Joshua: 
I think you're wrong about startssl being depreceated.
Looking at apachectl in a recent checkout, I see the line:
startssl|sslstart|start-SSL)
    $HTTPD -k start -DSSL
and in httpd.conf and ssl.conf, things are wrapped in <IfDefine SSL>.
creator: mads@apache.org
slive@apache.org
text:
Deprecated doesn't mean gone ;-)  Deprecated means the documentation says not to
use it.  (See the apachectl docs.)

I would prefer to get rid of the <IfDefine SSL> lines as well, but some others
seem to disagree.  I recommend that people who want SSL remove the <IfDefine>
lines or edit apachectl to add -DSSL to the main httpd invocation.

The whole concept of having to use a different command to start SSL doesn't
make sense to me.  Either you want SSL in the server, in which case it should
be started all the time, or you don't.

Just for the records. I agree with Joshua here. Since it's so easy to pass -DSSL
(if any) to apachectl a startssl option isn't really needed.
creator: nd@perlig.de

text: startssl has been removed from trunk.  This bug no longer matters.
